title-group.article-title: Effects of low-dose, long-term formaldehyde exposure on the structure and functions of the ovary in rats

article-meta.aff: 1Research Center of Reproductive Medicine, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, China
2The Children’s Hospital of Xi’an City, Xi’an, China
3Pathology Department, Medical School, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, China
4Key Laboratory of Environment and Genes Related to Diseases, Ministry of Education, Xi’an, China

author-notes.corresp: Dang-xia Zhou, Pathology Department, Medical School, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Yanta West Road, Xi’an 710061, China. Email: dangxia75@163.com

abstract.p: Formaldehyde (FA) is a ubiquitous environmental pollutant. However, the effects of FA exposure on reproduction are still a matter of scientific controversy. In this study, we assessed the ovarian toxicity of long-term, low-dose FA exposure in rats and explored the potential oxidative stress mechanisms. A total of 30 Sprague-Dawley female rats were randomly allotted to three groups, in which rats were exposed to FA at a dose of 0 mg/m3 (control), 0.5 mg/m3 and 2.46 mg/m3, respectively, by inhalation consecutively for 60 days. The results showed that the ovarian toxicity of FA is dose dependent. Ovarian structure and function in the group of rats exposed to 0.5 mg/m3 FA showed no obvious difference when compared with those in the control group. However, the activity of superoxide dismutase was significantly decreased, whereas the level of malondialdehyde was significantly increased in ovaries of rats exposed to 2.46 mg/m3 FA. Moreover, histopathological results demonstrated that the number and size of mature follicles significantly decreased, vascular congestion and interstitial edema in the ovaries of rats exposed to 2.46 mg/m3 FA. In conclusion, this study may suggest that the FA level of 0.5 mg/m3 can be considered as a safe level for FA exposure, but long-term FA exposure at a dose of 2.46 mg/m3 has a harmful effect on ovary by inducing oxidative stress.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Formaldehyde (FA) is an important chemical in the global economy (IARC, 2006). Over the last 20 years, China has experienced rapid economic growth and a simultaneous rise in demand for FA. As the most populous developing country in the world, China’s actual FA output has reached a staggering 12,000 kt in 2007, about 4000 times the amount five decades earlier (Zhu, 2008). Coinciding with the growth, FA pollution has also increased considerably in China, particularly in occupational settings (Tang et al., 2009]. FA exposure in environment occurs mainly via inhalation. Current occupational exposure limit (OEL) of FA in China is 0.5 mg/m3 (MOH, 2007). However, studies have shown that the levels of FA in some occupational environment were far higher than this limit (Fan et al., 2006; Zhang et al., 2007).

Human reproduction is a delicate process that can be influenced by many factors (Bretveld et al., 2008). As a ubiquitous environment contaminant, FA has long been suspected of causing adverse reproductive and developmental effects (Duong et al., 2011). However, the effects of FA exposure on female reproduction are still a matter of scientific controversy and inconclusive. Several human epidemiology studies have suggested that exposure of females to FA has been related to menstrual disorder, dysmenorrhea, genital infections and secondary infertility and adverse reproductive outcomes including spontaneous abortions, low birth weight and birth defects (Dulskiene and Grazuleviciene, 2005; John et al., 1994; Lu et al., 2007; Taskinen et al, 1999); but in the review of Collin et al. (2001) no such effects were indicated.

In animal studies, Guo-qing et al. (2010) demonstrated that FA has adverse effects on ovarian histopathology structure, oocyte ultrastructure in female rats and caused oocyte apoptosis. Saillenfait et al. (1989) reported fetotoxicity of FA at 20 ppm. Although evidence in animal experiments has accumulated in support of an association between female reproductive toxicity and FA exposure, most of these animal studies concerned the short-term effects of rather high dose of FA exposure. Short-term, high-dose exposure paradigms do not approximate real-life situations for human populations who may be subjected to possible long-term, low-level exposures (Tang et al., 2009).

Oxidative stress results from an imbalance between the excessive formations of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and limited antioxidant defenses. Oxidative stress is one of important mechanisms of ovary toxicity (Arikan et al., 2010; Pillai et al., 2010). Our previous studies have shown that FA has an adverse effect on testis and epididymis of male rats, inducing oxidative stress (Zhou et al., 2006a, 2006b, 2011a, 2011b) . However, to the best of our knowledge, there have been no experimental studies on the effects of long-term, low-level FA exposure on oxidative stress–related parameters in ovary.

In view of the above reasons, the present study was designed to investigate the potential effects of long-term, low-dose FA exposure on ovary, and oxidative stress was also assessed as a possible underlying mechanism.

sec.title: Animals and treatment
sec.p: A total of 30 healthy female Sprague-Dawley rats weighing 145–155 g were obtained from Experimental Animal Center of Xi’an Jiaotong University (China). Animals were housed in solid-bottomed polycarbonate cages in Specific Pathogen Free (SPF) animal laboratory with a temperature of 21–25°C and a relative humidity of 40%–60%. Rats were acclimatized at a 12-h light/12-h dark cycle and fed a standard diet and tap water ad libitum. Experiments were performed in accordance with the Animal Experimentation Committee Regulation.

The rats were divided at random into three groups, each comprising 10 individuals. Rats in FA exposure groups were given FA (Huagong, Xi’an, China) at a dose of 0.5 mg/m3 or 2.46 mg/m3, respectively, by inhalation in static toxification chambers. The treatment was conducted consecutively for 60 days at 8 h per day. Rats in the control group inhaled distilled water vapor.

sec.title: In-life observations
sec.p: All rats were observed at least twice per day, 7 days a week. Alterations in the skin and fur, mucous membranes and animal behavior were monitored.

sec.title: Radioimmunoassays of serum estradiol
sec.p: Before the rats were killed, the blood was collected from abdominal aorta into clean and dry test tubes. The blood samples were allowed to clot at room temperature and then centrifuged at 1500g for 10 min and serum was collected for hormone assays. The hormone radioimmunoassay kits were purchased from Jiu Ding Biotechnology Inc. (Tianjing, China). Serum estradiol (E2) was detected according to the instructions.

sec.title: Tissue preparation and histopathology
sec.p: At the end of the exposure, the rats were killed by an overdose of pentobarbital sodium (50 mg/kg given intraperitoneally) (Sigma, St Louis, USA) and the ovary was immediately removed and weighed. The ovary for histopathological study was fixed in fresh 10% neutral-buffered formalin solution and then dehydrated and embedded in paraffin; finally, 4 µm sections were cut and stained with hematoxylin–eosin (H&E). The tissue sections were observed under a light microscope.

sec.title: Assay of oxidative status and enzymatic antioxidant in ovaries
sec.p: According to our previous methods (Zhou et al., 2011a, 2011b), the ovary of each rat for biochemical study was immediately decapsulated, cleaned and washed in precooling physiological saline several times and homogenized in 0.1 mol/L precooling phosphate-buffered saline at a pH 7.4; the homogenate was centrifuged at 3000g for 15 min and the supernatant was used for biochemical assays. The activities of superoxide dismutase (SOD) and glutathione peroxidase (GSH-Px) and the level of malondialdehyde (MDA) in ovaries were detected using commercial assay kit (Jiancheng biotech Int., Nanjing, China).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: All statistical analyses were carried out using SPSS statistical software version 13.0 (SPSS, Chicago, IL, USA). At first, all data are tested for normal distribution (Shapiro-Wilks test) and homogeneity of variances (Bartlett test), defining whether the results should be analyzed parametrically or nonparametrically. Finally, statistical analysis was performed using one-way analysis of variance; p < 0.05 was considered as significant.

sec.title: General status of rats
sec.p: All female rats treated with and without FA survived the 60 days observation period, general status (skin and fur color and responsiveness) in the group of rats exposed to 0.5 mg/m3 FA showed no apparent differences when compared with those in the control group. However, part of the group of rats exposed to 2.46 mg/m3 FA showed less movement.

sec.title: Serum E2 concentrations
sec.p: Compared with the control group, serum E2 concentrations in rats treated with FA at 0.5 mg/m3 showed no statistically significant differences. Although slight decrease in serum E2 concentration was observed in the group of rats exposed to 2.46 mg/m3 FA, it showed no statistically significant difference when compared with those in the control group (Figure 1).

caption.p: Effect of long-term, low-dose FA exposure on serum E2 concentrations of rats. FA: formaldehyde; E2: estradiol.

sec.title: Ovarian weight
sec.p: The ovarian weight of two FA exposure groups and control group are summarized in Figure 2. There were no statistically significant differences in ovarian weight between low-dose (0.5 mg/m3 and 2.46 mg/m3) FA exposure groups and the control group (Figure 2).

caption.p: Effect of long-term, low-dose FA exposure on ovarian weights of rats. FA: formaldehyde.

sec.title: Ovarian morphology
sec.p: A group of follicles in various stages (primordial follicles, primary follicles, secondary follicle and mature follicle) and corpus luteum were seen in the section of ovary in control group (Figure 3(a)). Compared with the controls, there is no obvious change in ovarian morphology in the group of rats exposed to 0.5 mg/m3 FA.

caption.p: Light micrographs of ovarian sections stained with hematoxylin–eosin. (a) Ovary in control group (×100). (b) Ovary in a group of rats exposed to 2.46 mg/m3 FA, showing the number and size of mature follicles significantly decreased (×100). (c) Ovary in a group of rats exposed to 2.46 mg/m3 FA, showing vascular congestion (triangle) and increasing of atresia follicles (star; ×400). (d) Ovary in a group of rats exposed to 2.46 mg/m3 FA, showing structure disorder, interstitial edema (square), vascular congestion (triangle) and increasing of atresia follicles (star; ×400). FA: formaldehyde.

sec.p: However, in ovaries of rats exposed to 2.46 mg/m3 FA, the number and size of mature follicles significantly decreased (Figure 3(b)), whereas the number of atresia follicles obviously increased (Figure 3(c) and (d)). In addition, the ovary showed vascular congestion (Figure 3(c) and (d)), interstitial edema (Figure 3(d)) and structure disorder (Figure 3(d)).

sec.title: Ovarian biochemical analysis
sec.p: The activities of SOD in ovarian tissue of rats exposed to 2.46 mg/m3 FA group were significantly lower than those of the controls (p < 0.05; Table 1). Moreover, the contents of MDA in the ovarian tissue were found to be significantly increased in the group of rats exposed to 2.46 mg/m3 FA compared with those in the control group (Table 1).

caption.p: Effect of long-term, low-dose FA exposure on lipid peroxidation and antioxidative defense in ovaries of rats (mean ± SD, n = 10).

fn.p: FA: formaldehyde; SOD: superoxide dismutase; GSH-Px: glutathione peroxidase; MDA: malondialdehyde.
aWhen compared with the control group p < 0.05.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The present study is the first to demonstrate the effects of long-term, low-dose FA inhalation exposure on the ovary and to examine the possible oxidative stress mechanisms in rats. Our study showed that the ovarian toxicity of FA is dose dependent. Ovarian structure and function in the group of rats exposed to 0.5 mg/m3 FA showed no obvious difference when compared with those in control group. However, the activity of SOD was significantly decreased, while the level of MDA was significantly increased in ovaries of rats exposed to 2.46 mg/m3 FA. Moreover, histopathological results demonstrated that regressive histological changes including the number and size of mature follicles significantly decreased, vascular congestion, interstitial edema etc. in the ovaries of rats exposed to 2.46 mg/m3 FA.

FA exposure in environment occurs mainly via inhalation. However, many previous animal studies were conducted using unlikely exposure routes such as subcutaneous and intraperitoneal injection (Guo-qing et al., 2010; Hao and Wang, 2008). These exposure routes do not provide useful information to ascertain risk to human reproduction and development. For this reason, inhalation exposure was used in our present study for assessing potential ovarian toxicity in rats. In addition, current OEL for FA in China is 0.5 mg/m3 (MOH, 2007). Several countries employ time-weighted averages (TWAs) and/or short-term exposure limits (STELs). For example, the OEL in the United States is 0.75 ppm (0.92 mg/m3, 8 h TWA), with a STEL of 2 ppm (2.46 mg/m3; OSHA,1992), while in the United Kingdom it is 2 ppm (2.46 mg/m3) for both TWAs and STELs (HSE, 2007). Taken together, therefore, in this study we used a rat model to investigate the potential effect of long-term FA exposure on ovary by inhalation route at doses of 0.5 mg/m3 and 2.46 mg/m3, respectively.

General status, ovarian weight and histological structure, serum E2 concentration and ovarian biochemcial parameters of rats exposed to 0.5 mg/m3 FA showed no obvious differences when compared with those in the control group. These results clearly demonstrated that FA showed no obvious toxicity effects on structure and functions of ovary in rats at a concentration of 0.5 mg/m3, which further supported the view that current OEL for FA in China might be considered as a safe level for workers. However, in rats exposed to 2.46 mg/m3 FA, the number and size of mature follicles significantly decreased, vascular congestion and interstitial edema. Moreover, the activity of SOD was significantly decreased, whereas the level of MDA was significantly increased when compared with those in the control group. These findings suggested that long-term FA exposure at a dose of 2.46 mg/m3 has a harmful effect on structure and functions of ovary.

In this study, ovarian morphology and antioxidant parameters significantly decreased; however, the ovarian weight and serum E2 concentration showed no significant change in rats exposed to 2.46 mg/m3 FA. These results suggested that the morphology and the biochemical changes are more sensitive parameters in the evaluation of toxic effects on ovary, which supported the study of other authors (Gerez et al., 2005; Miyamoto et al., 2010).

Prooxidant and antioxidant balance is vital for normal biological functioning of the cells and tissues (Aly et al., 2009). SOD and GSH-Px are the most important enzymes in the antioxidant defense system, which are responsible for protecting tissues against the deleterious effects of ROS (Arikan et al., 2010). Oxidative stress occurs when the oxidative homeostasis is damaged (Fujii et al., 2003). Excessive ROS are generated and cause lipid peroxidation. MDA, a marker of tissue injury, is one of most important products of lipid peroxidation, which interfere in protein biosynthesis by forming adducts with DNA, RNA and protein (Doreswamy et al., 2004).

The results obtained in the current work demonstrated the obvious decrease in ovarian antioxidant enzyme SOD, while demonstrated a prominent increase in ovarian lipid peroxidation product MDA in rats exposed to 2.46 mg/m3 FA, which indicated the occurrence of oxidative stress in ovarian tissues. Inadequate protection from ROS active granulose and luteal cells could be a potential trigger for follicular atresia (Tsai-Turton and Luderer, 2006). Furthermore, ROS generated in the ovary induces apoptosis of granulose cells and changes in ovarian blood flow (Guven et al., 2010; Miyamoto et al., 2010). These findings further suggested that the altered ovarian antioxidant status might be associated with the changes in ovarian morphology structure.

In conclusion, our studies indicated a dose-dependant ovarian toxicity due to long-term, low-dose FA exposure. The current OEL (0.5 mg/m3) for FA in China might be considered as a safe level. However, long-term 2.46 mg/m3 FA exposure might induce ovarian toxicity by decreasing the activities of antioxidant enzymes and increasing lipid peroxidation, thereby causing oxidative stress in ovaries of rats. In view of the importance of human reproductive health and the current widespread usage of FA in China, it is very necessary to further investigate the correlation between FA exposure and female reproductive toxicity in the future.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research was supported by National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 30700654) and The Fundamental Research Funds for the Central University (XJJ 2011024).
